Award.AwardTitle: EPCN: Student Travel Grant Support for ACM e-Energy 2019. To Be Held at the Phoenix Convention Center in Phoenix, Arizona, June 25-28, 2019.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support student travel for attending ACM e-Energy 2019 (The Tenth International Conference on Future Energy Systems), which will be held at the Phoenix Convention Center in Phoenix, Arizona, June 25-28, 2019. The organizing committee will review applications and select 10 candidates that closely satisfy the participation criteria. Participation of early career post-docs and students in the ACM e-Energy will contribute to their education and provide them opportunities for career development by engaging them with the exchange of the newest ideas on this topic, presentation of their work, and networking with others. ACM e-Energy 2019 conference will contribute to the science, engineering and education on future energy systems, which will lead to the development of future energy systems that are cleaner, more efficient, and more sustainable. To broaden participation, women and students from underrepresented groups will be encouraged to apply.

The ACM e-Energy conference is aiming at promoting research and education at the intersection of computing, communication, and control of energy systems. ACM e-Energy specifically focuses on the application of new computing, communication and networking technologies to the control and operation of energy systems. Although still a young conference (in its 10th year in 2019), ACM e-energy has established itself as the premiere forum to attract professors, postdocs, researchers from national labs and industry, and students. Educating and engaging students and early-career post-doc researchers is one of the key objectives of ACM e-Energy. This funding will allow students and early-career post-doc researchers to attend the workshop to present their work, be exposed to new ideas, and network with other researchers and professors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The transformation of energy systems to be cleaner, more-efficient, and more renewable is critical to our sustainable future. However, such transformation also poses significant technical challenges to the operation, design and analysis of future energy systems. Traditional power systems based primarily on fossil-fuel generations relied on the control of the supply-side to meet demand. This operation paradigm is no longer effective when fossil-fuel is giving way to cleaner but more variable and uncertain renewables. Further, the system must integrate higher penetration of various demand-side resources and distributed energy resources, which are more difficult to control due to their scale in numbers and the uncertainty of their current states. Thus, there is a pressing need for bringing together advanced communication and computing technologies with the control of energy systems, to both make legacy systems more energy-efficient, and to design, analyze and operate innovative future energy systems.

The goal of this NSF travel support project is to provide travel support to students and early-career researchers, so that they can attend the 10th ACM e-Energy conference at Phoenix, AZ on June 25-28, 2019. ACM e-Energy is precisely aiming at promoting the research and education at the above intersection of computing, communication, and control of energy systems. By focusing on the application of new computing, communication and networking technologies to the control and operation of energy systems, the mission of ACM e-Energy matches perfectly that of the NSF EPCN program by integraing energy, power, control and networks. While still being a young conference (in its 10th year in 2019), ACM e-energy already establishes itself as the premiere forum bringing together professors, postdocs, researchers in industrial labs, engineers in the industry, and undergraduate/graduate students to shape the future of this area. Through this NSF travel grant support, students and early-career researchers are able to attend the conference, present their work, be exposed to new ideas, and network with other researchers and professors. Such experience will be crucial for their career development and future research.

Through a rigourous review process, the technical program of ACM e-Energy 2019 selected 26 full papers, 12 notes paper, and 27 posters. The conference featured 3 high quality workshop, 4 tutorials, 1 e-Energy kenote, and 3 FCRC keynotes. Applications for the travel grant were solicited through our mailing lists and to all authors of papers/notes/posters. Female students and students from under-represented groups were particularly encouraged to apply. After careful review of the applications, 12 awardees were chosen. Among them, 4 are women and 2 are minority. Further, 8 of the awardees are authors of full papers, 2 are authors of notes, and 2 are authors of posters. Finally, 11 of the awardees are students, and 1 is postdoc. All student travel grant awardees attended the conference. We expect that such experience will help their career development and future research, and will enable them to eventually become the new leaders of future energy systems.
